Award.AwardTitle: Travel Support for Student Participation in the 42nd Annual Meeting of the APS Division of Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics, Atlanta, GA
Award.AbstractNarration: This award provides funds for student travel to the 42nd Annual Meeting of the American Physical Society Division of Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics. The travel awards ensure the training and education of the next generation of scientists at this conference, widely accepted as the leading venue in the United States for atomic, molecular and optical physics. The science addressed includes control of quantum dynamics, cold atoms, dipolar quantum gases, molecular structure and spectroscopy, positron-matter interactions, antihydrogen, ultrafast and intense x-rays, single-atom optical interfacing, dipolar gases, interacting Bose gases, Fermi gases and magnetism, quantum measurement, strongly interacting cold gases, ultrafast molecular ionization and high harmonic generation, advances in gaseous electronics, interactions between hybrid quantum systems, fundamental symmetry tests, heavy particle collisions, atom circuits, atomic structure and spectroscopy, attosecond spectroscopy, fundamental symmetries and precision measurements, excitations in Bose and spinor gases, few-body and molecular collisions, uitrafast molecular dynamics, advances in quantum communication, cooling of atoms and molecules, photoionization spectroscopy, atomic clocks, cold collisions and photoassociation, recollision physics, quantum information methods, in-situ imaging of ultracold atomic gases, magnetism in optical lattices, quantum measurement and control of spin ensembles, ultracold molecules, degenerate quantum gases and alkaline earth atoms, time resolved spectroscopy, atomic and molecular photo-processes, progress in cavity opto-mechanics, few-body ultracold systems, collision studies, low temperature plasmas and Rydberg atoms, intense field physics, novel optical technologies and quantum information, synthetic gauge fields in ultracold systems, dissipation in cold atom systems, matter wave interferometry, nanoparticle structure and properties, and non-linear optics!

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
42st Annual DAMOP Meeting Support

 This grant provided support for the 42nd Annual Meeting of the American Physical Society – Division of Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics (APS - DAMOP). The meeting was held June 13-17, 2011 in Atlanta, Georgia at the Marriott Atlanta Marquis Hotel and Conference Center. The total attendance of 1121 was the highest attendance ever recorded. The attendance was approximately equally divided between senior scientists (e.g. research scientists, professors, post-docs) and graduate or undergraduate students. Those given support had not received APS DAMOP support in the past so this grant was partly responsible for their first attendance at the APS-DAMOP. Furthermore, student support was limited to only one grant per advisor so no single supervisor was treated preferentially and allowed to received a larger allocation of the support money. The support of diversity and equal opportunity to attend the meeting is made possible by the generous support of APS DAMOP from NSF.

The meeting has several key components including a graduate student symposium, a plenary session marking the opening of the scientific program and featuring presentations by the 2011 winners of the Rabi Prize in Atomic, Molecular and Optical Physics, Julius Edgar Lilienfeld Prize, Edward A. Bouchet Award, and George E. Valley, Jr. Award, general sessions consisting of six parallel oral sessions and three poster sessions, and numerous special events including a tutorial for authors and referees held by the editors of Physical Review and Physical Review Letters.


Last Modified: 07/16/2012
Modified by: Barry C Walker
